Title: Countable or uncountable set 8 signs
Content: Let S be a set of pairwise disjoint 8-like symbols on the plane. (The 8s may be inside each other as well) Prove that S is at most countable. Now I know you can "map" a set of disjoint intervals in R to a countable set (e.g. Q :rational numbers) and solve similar problems like this, but the fact that the 8s can go inside each other is hindering my progress with my conventional approach...
AcceptedAnswer: Let $\mathcal{E}$ denote the set of all your figure eights. Then, define a map $f:\mathcal{E}\to\mathbb{Q}^2\times\mathbb{Q}^2$ by taking $E\in\mathcal{E}$ to a chosen pair of rational ordered pairs, one sitting inside each loop. Show that if two such figure eights were to have the same chosen ordered pair, they must interesect, which is impossible. Thus, $f$ is an injection and so $\mathcal{E}$ is countable.
llm_answer_create_structured_problem:
###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
Each element of S is an 8-like symbol (a closed figure-8 curve) on the plane.
Any two distinct elements of S are pairwise disjoint (their images do not intersect).
Elements of S may be nested (one element may lie entirely within a region bounded by another element).
Problem:
Prove that S is at most countable.
###
